meta.title: Frequently Asked Questions
meta.subtitle: Common questions about HNF1B-related disease and our database

content.text: HNF1B-related disease refers to a spectrum of conditions caused by pathogenic variants in the **HNF1B** gene (Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1-Beta), also known as TCF2 (Transcription Factor 2). HNF1B is a transcription factor crucial for the development and function of the kidney, liver, intestine, and pancreatic beta cells.

items: **RCAD** (Renal Cysts and Diabetes Syndrome) - the most common presentation
**17q12 Deletion Syndrome** - often includes neurodevelopmental features
**CAKUT** (Congenital Anomalies of Kidney and Urinary Tract)

content.text: The condition follows autosomal dominant inheritance, though approximately 50% of cases occur de novo (new mutations not inherited from parents).

questions.question: What types of HNF1B variants are there?

content.text: HNF1B variants fall into several categories:

variants.title: 17q12 Deletion/Duplication
variants.description: Large ~1.4Mb deletions affecting HNF1B and neighboring genes. Most common variant type (~45% of cases).

variants.title: Missense Variants
variants.description: Single amino acid changes. May have dominant-negative effects on protein function.

variants.title: Truncating Variants
variants.description: Frameshift, nonsense, or splice site variants causing premature protein termination.

questions.question: What data does this database contain?

content.text: Data sources include a systematic literature review (1997-2021) and unpublished cohorts from collaborating centers.

questions.question: What data standards does the database use?

content.text: We use internationally recognized standards to ensure data interoperability:

items.text: **HPO** - Human Phenotype Ontology for phenotype annotation

questions.question: Can I access the data programmatically?

content.text: Yes! The database provides a RESTful API compliant with JSON:API v1.1 specification. You can:

items: Search by clinical and genetic parameters
Access aggregation endpoints for statistical summaries
Query variant annotations via Ensembl VEP integration

content.text: Variant pathogenicity is assessed according to **ACMG/AMP criteria** via InterVar, with subsequent manual curation by expert physicians. Variants are classified as:
Additional annotations include CADD scores, gnomAD population frequencies, and computational predictions from dbNSFP.

questions.question: How can I submit data to the database?

content.text: We welcome contributions from clinicians and researchers. To submit data:

items.text: **Curator access** can be granted for direct data entry through our web interface
**Bulk submissions** are possible via phenopacket JSON format

content.text: All data is reviewed by expert physicians before inclusion in the public database.
